Addis Emmet collection"}],"physdesc":[{"format":"structured","physdesc_components":[{"name":"extent","value":"30.83 linear feet"},{"name":"extent","value":"108 boxes, 21 volumes"}],"supress_display":true}],"abstract":[{"value":"The portion of the Emmet Collection housed in the Manuscripts and Archives Division consists of approximately 10,800 historical manuscripts relating chiefly to the period prior to, during, and following the American Revolution. The collection contains letters and documents by the signers of the Declaration of Independence as well as nearly every prominent historical figure of the period."}],"prefercite":[{"value":"
Thomas Addis Emmet collection, Manuscripts and Archives Division, The New York Public Library "}],"custodhist":[{"value":"
The Emmet Collection was assembled over a period of fifty years by Dr. Thomas Addis Emmet, a renowned surgeon and one of the early collectors of American manuscripts of the revolutionary era. His collection of 94 volumes of manuscripts and extra-illustrated books was purchased by John S. Kennedy and presented to The New York Public Library in 1896. "}],"scopecontent":[{"value":"
The portion of the Emmet Collection housed in the Manuscripts and Archives Division consists of approximately 10,800 historical manuscripts relating chiefly to the period prior to, during, and following the American Revolution. The collection contains letters and documents by the signers of the Declaration of Independence as well as nearly every prominent historical figure of the period. The manuscripts are arranged in 28 topics, most of them milestones in early American history. Topics include the Albany Congress of 1754, the Stamp Act Congress of 1765, the Continental Congresses, 1774 -1789, the Declaration of Independence, the Articles of Confederation, the Annapolis Convention, the Federal Convention, and the First Federal Administration. The Revolutionary War is well documented in the correspondence and letterbooks of generals and other officers, as well as in orderly books, muster rolls, and returns. Additional material documents the history of New York City. Highlights of the Emmet Collection include Thomas Jefferson's manuscript copy of the Declaration of Independence, an engrossed copy of the Bill of Rights, and manuscript minutes of the Annapolis Convention. "},{"value":"
The Thomas Addis Emmet collection is arranged in twenty-eight series:\n\n
The Albany Congress of 1754\n
The Stamp Act Congress of 1765\n
The Continental Congress of 1774\n
The Members of the Continental Congress, 1774-1779\n
The Presidents of Congress, and of the United States\n
The Declaration of Independence\n
The Signers to the Declaration of Independence\n
The Articles of Confederation\n
Lossing's Field Book of Revolution\n
The Siege of Savannah, 1779\n
The Siege of Savannah - Lincoln Papers\n
The Siege of Charleston - Lincoln Papers\n
The Generals of the American Revolution\n
Washington and His Military Family\n
The Annapolis Convention\n
The Federal Convention\n
The First Federal Administration\n
The Republican Court\n
Booth's History of New York\n
Francis' Old New York\n
Duer's Old Yorker\n
Irving's Life of Washington\n
Boundary Line Controversy\n
Howe's Virginia\n
Life of Edward Livingston\n
Life of Marion\n
General Leslie's Letterbook\n
Miscellaneous Manuscripts\n\n","type":"arrangement"}],"arrangement":[{"value":"
The Thomas Addis Emmet collection, 1483-1876, bulk (1700-1800) are organized into the following series:
The Albany Congress of 1754
The Stamp Act Congress of 1765
The Continental Congress of 1774
The Members of the Continental Congress, 1774-1779
New Hampshire, Massachusetts, Rhode Island, Connecticut
New York and New Jersey
Pennsylvania and Delaware
Maryland and Virginia

Donated by John S. Kennedy, 1896 "}],"separatedmaterial":[{"value":"
Most of the printed maps, printed documents, and graphic materials In the Emmet Collection have been transferred to other divisions of the Library: the Lionel Pincus and Princess Firyal Map Division; the Rare Book Division; and the Print Collection of the Miriam and Ira D. Wallach Division of Art, Prints and Photographs, respectively. this collection is digitized.

dd.p: Thomas Addis Emmet collection, Manuscripts and Archives Division, The New York Public Library

dl.dd: Advance notice required. Request access to this collection.
The entirety of this collection has been digitized and is available online.

div.p: The portion of the Emmet Collection housed in the Manuscripts and Archives Division consists of approximately 10,800 historical manuscripts relating chiefly to the period prior to, during, and following the American Revolution. The collection contains letters and documents by the signers of the Declaration of Independence as well as nearly every prominent historical figure of the period.
Digitization was made possible by a lead gift from The Polonsky Foundation.

The portion of the Emmet Collection housed in the Manuscripts and Archives Division consists of approximately 10,800 historical manuscripts relating chiefly to the period prior to, during, and following the American Revolution. The collection contains letters and documents by the signers of the Declaration of Independence as well as nearly every prominent historical figure of the period. The manuscripts are arranged in 28 topics, most of them milestones in early American history. Topics include the Albany Congress of 1754, the Stamp Act Congress of 1765, the Continental Congresses, 1774 -1789, the Declaration of Independence, the Articles of Confederation, the Annapolis Convention, the Federal Convention, and the First Federal Administration. The Revolutionary War is well documented in the correspondence and letterbooks of generals and other officers, as well as in orderly books, muster rolls, and returns. Additional material documents the history of New York City. Highlights of the Emmet Collection include Thomas Jefferson's manuscript copy of the Declaration of Independence, an engrossed copy of the Bill of Rights, and manuscript minutes of the Annapolis Convention.
The Thomas Addis Emmet collection is arranged in twenty-eight series:

div.a: The Members of the Continental Congress, 1774-1779
The Presidents of Congress, and of the United States
The Signers to the Declaration of Independence
The Siege of Savannah - Lincoln Papers
The Siege of Charleston - Lincoln Papers
The Generals of the American Revolution

div.p: The Emmet Collection was assembled over a period of fifty years by Dr. Thomas Addis Emmet, a renowned surgeon and one of the early collectors of American manuscripts of the revolutionary era. His collection of 94 volumes of manuscripts and extra-illustrated books was purchased by John S. Kennedy and presented to The New York Public Library in 1896.

Most of the printed maps, printed documents, and graphic materials In the Emmet Collection have been transferred to other divisions of the Library: the Lionel Pincus and Princess Firyal Map Division; the Rare Book Division; and the Print Collection of the Miriam and Ira D. Wallach Division of Art, Prints and Photographs, respectively.

li.a: Stamp Act Congress (1765 : New York, N.Y.)
New York (State) -- History -- Colonial period, ca. 1600-1775
